p.s: The following is an analysis of how John Worne presents his view on the learning of language in the UK.
He starts his text right away with the words can't, won't and don't.
In doing so, he expresses people's lack of interest in learning new languages.
Shortly afterwards he mentions that the number of students learinglearninga foreign language at a university has been falling for the last seven years.
In doing so, he supports his previous statement with regard to the lack of interest in acquiring new languages.
By relying on factual arguments, the reader becomes aware that there is a problem and the author is speaking of facts.
This in turn leads to the reader developing trust in the author and accepting the mentioned aspects better.
In line 13, John Worne compares the year 2015 with 1990.
He says that ten thousand fewer foreign language exams were absolved in 2015 than at the end of 1990, which once again illustrates the negative development.
The sentence on line 18 Perfectly intelligent people will tell you not to worry sounds pretty exageratedexaggerated and ironic.
In this way, the author arouses the reader's interest and wins their attention.
From line 18 he mentions the technology and invalidates each of the advantages that can arise from it with counter-statements.
He positions himself clearly on the side for learning a foreign language and against technology.
In addition he only mentions one positive thing in line 36, which also ensures that his point of view on the topic is clear and that you can see that he has no understanding of the rejection.
This becomes clear when he says that even more people need to take the chance to learn foreign languages (l. 39).
At the end he speaks directly to the parents again and talks to them with the request to get your children to learn a foreign language to fix the system (l. 46-50).
